e4: Adopting the new, unbiased reporting policy aligns with ethical practices and regulatory standards, promoting greater transparency and trust in financial reporting. Although there may be initial confusion among investors accustomed to the old reporting bias, clear communication and investor education can mitigate these effects. Maintaining integrity in financial reporting outweighs the short-term challenges, potentially improving investor relations and enhancing the company's reputation in the long run.
e5: An ethical reporting policy should be truthful, transparent, and consistent, providing accurate and complete information that avoids misleading stakeholders. It should comply with all regulatory requirements and standards. Furthermore, it should consider the potential impact on all investors, particularly ensuring that less informed, individual investors are not disadvantaged compared to more sophisticated market participants. Ethical reporting should actively prevent any perception of manipulative or deceptive practices and should be communicated clearly to ensure all stakeholders are adequately informed of any changes to reporting practices.
e6: How will the management ensure effective communication of the new unbiased reporting policy to all investors, including retail investors? What steps will be taken to educate them about this change to prevent misunderstandings? Also, how does the management plan to monitor and evaluate the impact of this policy change on the company's stock performance and investor relations in the short and long term?
